answer:
**Frame‐by‐Frame Analysis**  
• **Frame 1**: The roadway has multiple lanes; the pickup ahead is in the same lane as ego. To the right is a clearly defined shoulder/lane boundary. There are no cones yet in view, and no immediate obstructions in ego’s lane.  
• **Frame 2**: Signs on the right start indicating upcoming exits. Still no cones in ego’s lane. Pickup continues ahead in the same lane; no merging or lane‐closure arrows yet.  
• **Frame 3**: More signage: “Alpine Road, ¾ mile,” and “Palo Alto University Next Exit.” The lane lines remain continuous, and the pickup stays in the same lane.  
• **Frame 4**: Cones become visible on the right, suggesting work or a partial closure in or near the right lane/shoulder. Ego’s lane appears unobstructed.  
• **Frame 5**: The cones line the right‐side lane/shoulder, guiding traffic away from the rightmost side. The pickup remains stable in the current (left‐center) lane; there is no sign that ego’s lane itself is ending or must exit.  

**Contextual Reasoning**  
The coned area is off to the right (likely a closed exit/shoulder or work zone). There are no indications that the ego‐lane is forced off or merging. Stopping on a freeway lane is unwarranted unless there is an emergency. A lane change to the right would place ego into (or near) the coned/off‐ramp area. A lane change to the left is also not prompted by any hazard or sign telling us to move over.  

**Match to Answer Choices**  
• **A. Lane change to the left** – Not justified. The left lane is free, but there is no reason to move left.  
• **B. Lane change to the right** – Inadvisable due to the cones and potential closure.  
• **C. Continue in the current lane** – Safest action given the lane is open and unobstructed.  
• **D. Come to a stop** – Not appropriate on a moving freeway with no immediate hazard.  

**Best Answer**  
<answer>C</answer>
